TEI.2.document_title: Stephen F Austin to Carlos Garcia, Minister of Relations, 08-01-1833

barker_notes.barker_summary: Austin to Minister of Relations, Mexico, August 1, 1833. Argument supporting claims of Texas to separate statehood. Separation from Mexico would be a calamity, but continued union with Coahuila would be worse.
barker_notes.barker_footnotes: University of Texas Transcripts from Archives of Department of Fomento, Mexico. The translation is by Mrs. Margaret Kress, instructor in Spanish, the university of Texas. A statement of the resources of Texas is omitted. It can be found in the Southwestern Historical Quarterly, October, 1924, XXVIII, 118-121.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 992-996

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to Minister of Relations, Mexico, August 1, 1833. Argument supporting claims of Texas to separate statehood. Separation from Mexico would be a calamity, but continued union with Coahuila would be worse.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*[In closure]*/p* *p**person_mentioned*Austin */person_mentioned*to *person_mentioned*Minister of Relations*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p*For the better explanation of the representation of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, soliciting that she be admitted as a *location_mentioned*state of the Mexican Federation*/location_mentioned*, I present the following bases on which are founded her rights to be a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*1st. She possesses sufficient qualifications, and the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* have manifested their desire to be a state.*/p*
*p*2nd. The natural right that she has always had of organizing herself as a state, and of occupying her rank as such, at the side of her sisters the *location_mentioned*other states*/location_mentioned*, on account of having been a *location_mentioned*distinct province*/location_mentioned* at the time of the independence.*/p*
*p*3rd. The guarantee of the law of *date_mentioned n="05-07-1824">May 7, 1824*/date_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*4th. The right that is guaranteed to her by the system adopted by the *location_mentioned*Mexican Republic*/location_mentioned*, of promoting her welfare, and of securing her interior prosperity and tranquility by an adequate organization of her *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*5th. The duty, and the interest of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, of cementing and assuring her permanent union with the *location_mentioned*Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*6th. The right that all people have of saving themselves from anarchy and from utter ruin.*/p*
Explanation of these "bases"
*p*1st. The declaration of the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* that they have the elements sufficient to form a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*, and the fact that they are ready to be charged with the expenses and responsibilities of the *person_mentioned*interior administration*/person_mentioned* is proof that they are in a condition to figure as a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*, because it is very evident that they would not have solicited such a thing if they were not satisfied of their capacity physical and moral, to sustain the *person_mentioned*administration */person_mentioned*and to fulfill all the duties of a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*. For a better explanation of this point I refer to the statistical report which is hereto attached.*/p*
*p*2nd. The provisional union of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*with *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*by the law of *date_mentioned n="05-07-1824">May 7, 1824*/date_mentioned*, was without the formal or cordial consent of the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*, or of her *person_mentioned*deputy in the general constituent congress*/person_mentioned*; and that union could not destroy the natural and primitive right of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to organize as a state when in the opinion of her *person_mentioned*inhabitants */person_mentioned*their necessities might require it.*/p*
*p*The natural rights of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*in this particular are recognized in the said law by the fact that the union with *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*is conditional and provisional, and not positive and permanent*/p*.
*p**location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*does not recognize, nor can recognize, that she has to ask the approbation of three-fourths of the *location_mentioned*states of the federation*/location_mentioned*, in order to be admitted as a distinct member of the *person_mentioned*Mexican */person_mentioned*family. This right always has belonged to her and does belong to her and if the exercise of the right has been postponed until now it has been by voluntary consent of her *person_mentioned*inhabitants*/person_mentioned*, and not because they have believed, or believe, that their union with *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*has weakened it in the least particle. It is a natural right, and as such it is imprescriptible, sacred, and inviolable, and cannot be destroyed except in case the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* should abandon it, and this they have never done.*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*does not admit the principle that *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*has a voice or consent in the question of her right to be erected into a *location_mentioned*State*/location_mentioned*; nor can she ask of *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*as a favor what belongs to her by right and by justice.*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*does not desire a hand's breadth of the *location_mentioned*territory of Coahuila*/location_mentioned*. If there is a doubt concerning the division line of the old *location_mentioned*provinces of Coahuila and Texas*/location_mentioned*, or other peculiar questions, they must be settled between those two states in a friendly manner or in conformity with the laws governing such cases.*/p*
*p*3rd. The law of *date_mentioned n="05-07-1824">May 7, 1824,*/date_mentioned* is very clear and well defined, and recognizes the natural right of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*of erecting herself into a state, and concedes to her the privilege of manifesting to the *person_mentioned*general congress*/person_mentioned* her desire to be a state, when in the opinion of her *person_mentioned*inhabitants */person_mentioned*she has the elements to figure as such. That law does not contain the provision of asking the approbation of three- fourths of the states before *person_mentioned*congress */person_mentioned*shall consider the petition of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to be admitted as a state; and *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*considers herself in the same situation as to the formalities of her admission as was occupied by *location_mentioned*Nuevo Leon*/location_mentioned*, *location_mentioned*Durango*/location_mentioned*, and *location_mentioned*Chihuahua */location_mentioned*in their time; with the difference that there is a guarantee, a solemn contract between the *location_mentioned*nation */location_mentioned*and *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*that she will be formed into a state when she possesses the qualifications to figure as such.*/p*
*p*4th. The glory of the federal system consists in the fact that no other form of government invented by the wisdom of men, has been able to meet the local necessities of each angle of an immense *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, and at the same time to unite the physical and moral force of all parts in a*location_mentioned* national center*/location_mentioned* in order to work in mass, in defense of their liberty and independence.*/p*
*p*The objects of this system are clearly defined in the paragraph of the discourse directed by the *person_mentioned*general constituent congress*/person_mentioned* to the *person_mentioned*Mexican people*/person_mentioned*, which begins with the words, "The *location_mentioned*federal republic*/location_mentioned* has been and ought to be the fruit of their discussions," etc. These same principles are recognized in Article 26 of the Constitution of the *location_mentioned*state of Coahuila and Texas*/location_mentioned*, which says, "the object of the *person_mentioned*government of the state*/person_mentioned* is the happiness of the *person_mentioned*individuals */person_mentioned*who compose it, understanding that the end of all political society is no other than the welfare of its associates."*/p*
*p*The petition of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*is sanctioned and supported by all these fundamental principles, because it is very evident that *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*cannot be governed by *location_mentioned*Coahuila*/location_mentioned*, and consequently " the welfare of the associates " imperiously demands that she be made a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*5th. The *person_mentioned*inhabitants of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* desire to cement and strengthen their union with the *location_mentioned*Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*, and it is their most important interest and their duty to do it.*/p*
*p*There is no *person_mentioned*individual */person_mentioned*in *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*who is not convinced that the greatest misfortune that could happen to him would be the separation of that *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned* from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*: neither is there any one who does not know very well that her union indirectly by means of *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*is in the highest degree precarious and liable to be broken without great difiiculty.*/p*
*p*It is known by certain things, positive facts, that *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*cannot govern *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*; and the latter cannot remain, and will not remain in harmony or quietude united with the former.*/p*
*p*Another truth is, that it is useless to try to subject or regulate *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*by *person_mentioned*military */person_mentioned*force.*/p*
*p*That *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*has to be governed by moral force, and her union with *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned* strengthened and established by the principles of the federal system, and those of the century in which we live.*/p*
*p*In conformity with these principles the object of the *person_mentioned*government */person_mentioned*is, the happiness and prosperity of the *person_mentioned*people*/person_mentioned*, and " the welfare of the associates." If these objects are fulfilled in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, she will be united to *location_mentioned*Mexico */location_mentioned*by bonds much stronger than those which could result from an *person_mentioned*army */person_mentioned*of fifty thousand men.*/p*
*p*Interest is the most powerful bond that operates upon the actions and desires of humanity. By the application of this fundamental principle to *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, all erroneous ideas vanish in a moment, and also the false rumors that may have existed concerning the danger of the *location_mentioned*Mexican territory*/location_mentioned* in that *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*The interests of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*are, to cement her union with *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, and to have a *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned* as a state of this *location_mentioned*federation*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*These interests are the natural bonds that unite and always will unite *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to the *location_mentioned*Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*. But the last is of so much importance, and so indispensably necessary to the " welfare " and " happiness " of that people, that it cannot be omitted or delayed. Consequently if there were no way of obtaining it without breaking the bonds of the union with *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, it would then be the interest of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to attempt her separation.*/p*
*p*This point has been discussed and examined with much frankness in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*; and the opinion is formed and established upon very solid, unalterable foundations, because it has been the result of much reflection; that opinion is, that it would be a misfortune to be separated from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, but that it would be a greater misfortune not to be erected into a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*, so as to be able to organize her *person_mentioned*local government*/person_mentioned*. There are well founded fears that *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*may have to suffer the first misfortune in order to save herself the last; and these fears have had a dominating influence in the desire for separation from *location_mentioned*Coahuila*/location_mentioned*, for the purpose of reconciling with one voice all the local interests of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned* with her permanent union with the *location_mentioned*Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*I have said, and I repeat it, it is not the interest of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to separate herself from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, even if she had full liberty to do it. If the *person_mentioned*Government */person_mentioned*should wish to know the reasons on which this opinion is founded, I will present them in a separate paper, and in the same I will demonstrate that the true interest of *location_mentioned*Coahuila */location_mentioned*and of all the *location_mentioned*republic */location_mentioned*demands that *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*should be made a state without any delay.*/p*
*p*6th. This is a dark and very gloomy point. *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*is to-day exposed to separation from *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*—to being the sport of *person_mentioned*ambitious men*/person_mentioned*, of *person_mentioned*speculators*/person_mentioned* and reckless *person_mentioned*money-changers*/person_mentioned*, of seditious and wicked men, of *person_mentioned*wandering Indians*/person_mentioned* who are devastating the *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, of *person_mentioned*adventurers*/person_mentioned*, of revolution, of the lack of the administration of justice and of confidence and moral strength in the *person_mentioned*government*/person_mentioned*. In short, for the want of government that *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*is already at the verge of anarchy.*/p*
*p*If one proceeded in accordance with the laws of the *location_mentioned*state of Coahuila and Texas,*/location_mentioned* a respectable man would not be safe either in person or property; nor would the *person_mentioned*capitalist */person_mentioned*be secure in his capital. If crime is punished, it has to be done extrajudicially without paying attention to the laws and forms established, and this affords a dangerous example to society and a subversion of the moral strength which the government and the laws ought to have. On the other hand, if crimes go unpunished, the vices are unbridled and all the safeguards of society are destroyed.*/p*
*p*For a long time the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* have rested in regard to their personal security and that of their property, rather upon the virtues which exist in the honor of the mass of the people than upon the administration of the laws.*/p*
*p*To suppose that such a state of affairs can continue would be to venture much; in short, it would be to suppose an impossibility.*/p*
*p*If the only radical remedy which these evils admit is not applied without delay, that of establishing *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*as a state, it will fall into anarchy; and whence it will go from that is not in the power of man's judgment to say, or what injury will result to the *location_mentioned*frontiers */location_mentioned*of *location_mentioned*Coahuila*/location_mentioned*, *location_mentioned*Nuevo Leon*/location_mentioned*, and *location_mentioned*Tamaulipas*/location_mentioned*, for it is very certain that the *person_mentioned*Indians */person_mentioned*will take advantage of the occasion to begin hostilities and depredations, and thousands of *person_mentioned*adventurers */person_mentioned*will be set in motion.*/p*
*p*A state of anarchy in *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*would also cause confusion upon the *location_mentioned*frontiers of Louisiana and Arkansas*/location_mentioned*; and in such case the probability is great that the *person_mentioned*government of the north*/person_mentioned* would take posession of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*in order to preserve order upon their *location_mentioned*frontiers */location_mentioned*as it did in the case of the *location_mentioned*Floridas*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*All this and incalculable other evils would be avoided by establishing *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned* as a *location_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*I cannot imagine anything more urgent for the exercise of extraordinary powers than this, since by its exercise in this matter the integrity of the *location_mentioned*territory */location_mentioned*may be preserved, *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*and her *person_mentioned*inhabitants */person_mentioned*may be saved—and a new and strong column may be raised to sustain the great edifice of the *location_mentioned*Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*In view of what was set forth in this paper and of the representation of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, I beg that *person_mentioned*Your Excellency*/person_mentioned*, the *person_mentioned*Vice President*/person_mentioned*, may be pleased to make use of the extraordinary powers to decree that *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*shall form a *location_mentioned*state of the Mexican federation*/location_mentioned*, and that she may proceed without delay to organize as such.*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*, *date_mentioned n="08-01-1833">August 1, 1833*/date_mentioned*.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Stephen F. Austin*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*To *person_mentioned*His Excellency the minister of Relations, Don Carlos Garcia*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*/div1*
